text:
Did you know that the trillions of microorganisms
living inside your gut weigh about as much

as your brain? Or that microbes made “gut”
a totally acceptable science word and not

just something your party bros have? We’ve
started calling all the microbes inhabiting

our bodies the microbiome. And guys, it is
so hot right now.

If you’re wondering why everyone is so stoked
on your crobes these days, stick around and
we’ll explain the hype.

Hey everyone, Matt here. The Speaking of Chemistry
posse got its collective guts to Boston to

visit Harvard chemist Emily Balskus and learn
more about the microbiome.

Over the past decade, researchers have learned
a ton about the genetics of the microorganisms

living in and on our bodies. Emily and her
team are now decoding that genetic information

to find out how microbes produce molecules
that affect our health, for better or worse.
Emily Balskus: What we really need to do to take our understanding of the microbiome to the next level,

to really try to understand whether these organisms
are impacting human biology, what are the mechanisms

underlying this influence, we really need
to understand what these organisms are doing.

Matt: Success on this front could mean huge
things for healthcare. For instance, researchers

could look at what molecules microbes are
making in healthy people to identify promising

new drug candidates. Understanding microbial
activity in sick patients could also give
doctors clues for new treatments.

And the Harvard team is already making progress here.
In 2012, they discovered an enzyme made by

our gut bacteria that takes choline, found
in things like eggs, broccoli and cauliflower,

and converts it into trimethylamine. This
molecule is made only by bacteria and it looks

like most of us have li’l buddies making
trimethylamine in our guts. So trimethylamine

isn’t necessarily bad news, but it can cause
trouble.

The compound smells like rotting fish, or
more accurately, rotting fish smell because

of this molecule. People with a rare metabolic
disorder called fish odor syndrome can’t

convert trimethylamine into less pungent compounds
and release the molecule in their sweat and

breath. There’s no cure for it. Researchers
also believe trimethylamine plays a role in
a far more common condition: heart disease.

Now that they’ve found this enzyme--called
choline trimethylaminelyase--Emily and her

team can study its biochemical properties
in the lab. They can also determine which

gut bacteria are producing it and, potentially,
if any trouble-makers are making too much of it.

Researchers like Emily are just starting to
drill down into the profound chemical connection

between us and our microbes. And that’s
pretty darn exciting. Isn’t that right, Crobee?
Crobee: You said it, Matty!
